content.description:
Legit1 titulumtitulus, -i, m.: placard auditoque pretiopretium, -i, n.: price, quia suspectasuspicio, -ere, -spexi, -spectum: to suspect vilitasvilitas, -atis, f.: cheapness, 
percunctatuspercunctor, -ari, -atus sum: to ask about omnia docetur ac nihilominusnihilominus, adv.: nevertheless, immoimmo, adv.: on the contrary tanto 
magis conducitconduco, -ere: to rent. Ubi coepit advespadvesperasco, -ere: to get close to eveningeadvesperasco, -ere: to get close to the eveningrascereadvesperasco, -ere: to get close to evening, iubet sterni sibi 
in prima domus parte, poscit pugillarespugillares, -ium, m. pl. = tabula, -ae, stilum, lumen, suos 

omnes in interiorainterior, -oris, adj.: inner dimittitdimitto, -ere = mitto, -ere; ipse ad scribendum animum, 
oculos, manum intendit, ne vacua mens audita simulacrasimulacrum, -i, n. = imago, -inis et 
inanesinanis, -e, adj.: empty sibi metus fingeret.

Epistulae 7.27.7
 1:The subject of legit is Athenodorus.↩
content.question:
Answer the following question(s) in English unless the question specifically asks you to provide Latin words.

Describe one and only one of Athenodorus’s reactions in lines 1-3 (Legit...conducit) to learning about the house before he rents it. 

Provide the Latin word(s) that support your answer in Part (i).

Translate in context the Latin word(s) you cited in Part (ii).
